revision:
1. The numbers \(1, 2, 3, 4,........\) are called natural numbers and denoted by N.
  2. The numbers \(0, 1, 2, 3, 4,........\) are called whole numbers and denoted by W.
  3. The numbers \(.....-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4,.....\) are called integers and denoted by Z.
  4. A number \(r\) is called a rational number, if it can be written in the form \( rac{p}{q}\), where \(p\) and \(q\) are integers and \(q eq 0\).
  5. A number \(s\) is called a irrational number, if it cannot be written in the form \( rac{p}{q}\), where \(p\) and \(q\) are integers and \(q eq 0\).
  6. The decimal expansion of a rational number is either terminating or non-terminating recurring. Moreover, a number whose decimal expansion is terminating or non-terminating recurring is rational.
  7. The decimal expansion of an irrational number is non-terminating non-recurring. Moreover, a number whose decimal expansion is non-terminating non-recurring is irrational.
  8. All the rational and irrational numbers make up the collection of real numbers.
  9. There is a unique real number corresponding to every point on the number line. Also, corresponding to each real number, there is a unique point on the number line.
  10. If \(r\) is rational and \(s\) is irrational, then \(r + s\) and \(r - s\) are irrational numbers, and \(r.s\) and \( rac{r}{s}\) are irrational numbers, \(r eq 0\).
  11. For positive real numbers \(a\) and \(b\), the following identities hold :
    • \(\sqrt{ab}=\sqrt{a}\sqrt{b}\)
    • \(\sqrt{ rac{a}{b}}= rac{\sqrt{a}{\sqrt{b}}\)
    • \((\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b})(\sqrt{a}-\sqrt{b})=a-b\)
    • \((\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b})^2=a+2\sqrt{a}\sqrt{b}+b\)
    • \((\sqrt{a}-\sqrt{b})^2=a-2\sqrt{a}\sqrt{b}+b\)
    • \((\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b})(\sqrt{c}+\sqrt{d})=\sqrt{ac}+\sqrt{ad}+\sqrt{bc}+\sqrt{bd}\)
  12. To rationalise the denominator of \( rac{1}{\sqrt{a} - b}\), we multiply this by \( rac{\sqrt{a}+b}{\sqrt{a}+b}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.
  13. Let a>0 be a real number and \(p\)and \(q\) be rational numbers. Then
    • \(a^m.a^n=a^{m+n}\)
    • \(a^{(m)^n}=a^{m.n}\)
    • \( rac{a^m}{a^n}=a^{m-n}\)
    • \(a^m.b^m=(a.b)^m\)
    • \(a^{ rac{m}{n}}=\sqrt[n]{a^m}=(\sqrt[n]{a})^m\)
